replies.author: @alebassista
replies.text:
We have an Italian guy who literally fought in Donbass, with the People's Republics, who managed to win the legal procedures against him once he repatriated, which was before the special operation (so before NATO took an overt stance in the conflict and labelled Russia as an actual enemy). He fought in the early internationalist militias and managed to WIN legal scrutiny against him. Others went to bring food and supply to civilians in Donbass and they didn't get jailed too, because it wasn't illegal. 

Hinkle didn't go in Donbass to fight against the Russians, but didn't engage in action deemed illegal and was still under scrutiny. How can you say that he went in Donbass for the US gov, as a fed, if he didn't do: 1 anything in support to us policy; 2 anything ILLEGAL against us policy at the point that the absence of legal repercussions would make the lack of it suspicious?

What is hard to understand, literally?

You could go to Russia tomorrow, or at the Sochi Youth Conference. They will search your arse once you're back in the US, but they can't jail you for it. Would that make you a fed too?

Veterans for Peace is an org under us scrutiny and they likely do more for peace, and by extension also the working people of not just the US, than you. And they served in the military of the empire. And they still bring more to the cause than, probably, you, assuming that you are an ordinary fella like most of the people around. I'd friendly recommend you get a grip, especially if you consider yourself anywhere versed in historical and dialectical materialism.

replies.author: @alebassista
replies.text: Oh, before I'm misunderstood, for "we" I don't mean I'm an ACP member. I'm not even from North America.

replies.author: @Kawa856
replies.text: @SiriuslyKrazee It's not illegal to go to Donbass ffs... People like Dan Kovalik have gone there many times and even recently returned. You get harassed at the airport and have your electronic devices confiscated (returned later, but obviously bugged at that point.), but you don't get arrested for it. Also, why would the U.S state department want him to go to Donbass, literally makes no sense if you think about it for 5 seconds.

replies.author: @Kawa856
replies.text: @alebassista To be clear, Hinkle went on the Russian side, which is why this point is so moronic. Why would the US state department want a popular US media personality (even if alternative and heavily suppressed) to go to Donbass and show the destruction to homes and civilian infrastructure by NATO weapons.

author: @likeabossk4055
text: Hasan is being painted as 'the' left wing by the right, he talks about things that are popular opposition points but does not address the root cause in any meaningful way nor how to tackle it. He actively takes actions to discredit the left by talking down on other left wingers as well as promoting actions that are not in line with other socialists (while being portraited as the socialist model). Examples being that he only talks about things that are somewhat popular to not like about the establishment, but when it comes to his issues with the left he goes to CNN and talks crap about them and even lies to what they are which in turn gains him clout. His actions against the establishment have been words with little meaning to them, while his actions towards the left have been specifically targeted to discredit them and push the image of socialism down. I guess in some ways what I am saying is that his backlash against the left is louder than the one against the establishment. Already from this it makes things pretty clear that he is a controlled opposition, to appeal to the people that already disagree but to gate them from becoming a threat to the system, and at the very best to turn them the other way around. To give some perspective; as a real socialist the enemy number one is the capitalist establishment, even though you may not agree on some points with other socialists you don't fight with your brothers. Once you turn your back on your brothers and start attacking them, that is the point you have lost your sense and become a tool for the capitalists, it is called divide and conquer. Whether Hasan is a direct right wing agent or not, he has deemed it acceptable to align with the establishment against the left wing movement for his own gain and that itself marks him as a collaborator, basically he was bought up if not already from the start.

author: @ozzie3432
text:
This platform was my first introduction to the scientific sociaIist perspective when I found it on tiktok a couple of years ago. While I appreciate what you've done in the past, it seems like this platform is going down a strange path. Unfortunately, it seems like people aren't ready to take any criticism without responding in an argumentative way.

As for Hasan, if you assume the worst of him, it makes sense for him to assume the worst of you. I definitely had a "f hasan" moment and still have plenty of criticism for him since I think he can be more Ieft. However, he's still the biggest Ieftist platform and people like him because he is entertaining. His platform is a tool and it makes sense to work with him than against him. His platform is good for bringing in people who are uninformed and pushing them towards a more Ieftist direction. He showed that when he platformed Second Thought, the Deprogram podcast, More Perfect Union, BadEmpanada, The Kavernacle, and other platforms that inform people from a sociaIist perspective. This Ieftist infighting stuff isn't helpful.

author: @vicekind9354
text: I think it's mostly due to your conservative positions. You don't have to fly the progressive flag, have pride workshops, scream from the hills that you love pronouns. In fact you don't even have to mention it. It would just behoove you to treat marginalized groups like the LGBTQ welcomed because otherwise that would just be a point used against you by the right. You can have a pro family message while also working with LGBTQ comrades not in starting a meeting with saying your pronouns or virtue signal every time you have screen time like a lot of leftist orgs do, but simply stating that you will safeguard their rights while also safeguarding the future for working families. At that point no naysayers liberal or otherwise can attack your positions.

author: @denizen7even
text: I get that the American revolution was groundbreaking for its time in terms of personal liberties and such, but let's not forget who those liberties were for, cuz they certainly  weren't for the indigenous natives. I get having a "national identity" worked for Russia because Russia has always been fairly ethnohomogenous. This doesn't work in the U.S. because you'd have to glorify the history of this country, which was founded on slavery and genocide. There has to be something else we can all come together on, cuz I find it difficult to see support for Marxism/Leninism from indigenous people. At least the way I understood yall describe it. But maybe I'm wrong. I feel like instead of looking to the past for national identity, we can maybe "look into the future" to what this country can be. A true melting pot of immigrants, hell, a utopia even.

replies.author: @lain2006gits
replies.text: You are wrong, but on the right track. On country wasn't founded on just the genocide of the natives, you're tunnel visioning here. There's a reason why Lenin, ho chi Minh and Stalin uphold the revolution as it was break from European dominance and the establishment of a new state and world. Read what paine, Jefferson and Washington actually talk about. The melting pot is our future , only because of our past

replies.text: The Czarist Empire was called the "prisonhouse of nations," nations in this context meaning many different ethnic groups. Soviet identity had to be built, it wasn't inherited from the Russian Empire. I am of the opinion that a new sense of identity (preferably socialist identity) can be built here as well, and it doesn't require glorification of the rot of our past.
